Class Utilities

java.lang.Object
utils.Utilities
public class Utilities extends Object
The responsibility of the Utilities class is to provide utility methods used throughout the application.

Purpose

  • Truncating and validating string lengths.
  • Converting boolean values to/from specific formats.
  • Ensuring numeric values fall within certain ranges.
  • Prompting the user to try an action again in case of invalid input, improving user experience.
This class was provided in the assignment spec, with the exception of the tryAgain() method.

  • Method Details

    • toTwoDecimalPlaces

      public static double toTwoDecimalPlaces(double number)
      This method takes in a decimal point number and truncates it to two decimal places. Note that the method does NOT round when truncating; the numbers after the two decimal places are just removed. The method does the truncating in this manner: - multiply the number by 100 e.g. 16.543235523 * 100 = 1654.3235523 - cast the multiplied number as an in e.g. 1654.3235523 = 1654 - finally, the multiplied and casted number is divided by 100 and returned e.g. 1654 = 16.54
      Parameters:
      number - Number to be truncated to two decimal places
      Returns:
      the number, passed as a parameter, truncated to two decimal places (note: not rounded)

    • YNtoBoolean

      public static boolean YNtoBoolean(char charToConvert)
      This method returns true if the charToConvert value is Y or y. Returns false in all other cases.
      Parameters:
      charToConvert - The char value that will be used to determine true/false.
      Returns:
      Returns true if the charToConvert value is Y or y. Returns false otherwise.

    • booleanToYN

      public static char booleanToYN(boolean booleanToConvert)
      This method returns Y if the booleanToConvert value is true. Returns N otherwise.
      Parameters:
      booleanToConvert - The boolean value that will be used to determine Y/N
      Returns:
      Returns Y if the booleanToConvert value is true. Returns N otherwise.

    • truncateString

      public static String truncateString(String stringToTruncate, int length)
      This method returns a string that was passed as a parameter, truncated to a specific length, also passed as a parameter. If the original String is less than the passed length, then the original string is just returned.
      Parameters:
      stringToTruncate - The string that will be truncated to a specific length
      length - The length to which to truncate the string to
      Returns:
      The string truncated to a specific length

    • validateStringLength

      public static boolean validateStringLength(String strToCheck, int maxLength)
      This method takes in a string, passed as a parameter and valdiates whether it is less than or equal to a specific length or not.
      Parameters:
      strToCheck - The string that will be checked to see if it is a specific length
      maxLength - The length that the string will be validated against
      Returns:
      True if the string is less than or equal the max length and false otherwise.

    • validRange

      public static boolean validRange(int numberToCheck, int min, int max)
      This method returns true if the numberToCheck is between min and max (both inclusive)
      Parameters:
      numberToCheck - The number whose range is being checked.
      min - The minimum range number to check against (inclusive)
      max - The maximum range number to check against (inclusive)
      Returns:
      Returns true if the numberToCheck is between min and max (both inclusive), false otherwise.

    • tryAgain

      public static boolean tryAgain()
      Prompts the user to try again, then converts the user's response to a boolean value. Driver uses the Boolean response to do something, i.e. call the method from which it was invoked again to give the user a chance to re-enter/correct details. This method was added to avoid the user needing to go through the menu process again, including re-displaying the menu, when an input is deemed invalid.

      This method:
      • Asks the user: "Would you like to try again? [Y/N] => "
      • Reads the userâ€™s char input ("Y" or "y", case-insensitive due to readNextChar(char) implementation).
      • Converts the character to a boolean:
        • "Y" or "y" => true
        • "N" or "n" => false
      Any character input other than "Y"/"y"/"N"/"n" is handled by readNextChar(char). This will ask the user to re-input the character if it's not valid.
      Returns:
      true if the user enters "Y" or "y", false if the user enters "N" or "n" or any other character.
